Description: Body sherd of Chian Simple Animal Style pottery chalice; white slip; interior: glazed streaky black; part of lotus bud in added white outline with added red centre above two white lines; exterior: lion (lower body and part of head missing) to right; below in handle zone, double saw-edged metope band with set of verticals to right; band below and traces of decoration on lower wall.
Excavator/field collector: Excavated by: Dr David George Hogarth
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Ashmolean Museum, Oxford. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Lemos describes this sherd as belonging to the first stage of the Group of the Simple Figures. Some sherds in this group have the double-edged saw pattern in the handle zone. The fabric of the sherd was analysed by the Research Laboratory for Archaeology at Oxford. Using Ward's Method Cluster Analysis (WMCA) and Principal Components Analysis (PCA), it was found that the fabric originated in the Kampos plain in the east of the island of Chios (Jones with J.Boardman in Jones 1986, p.286).
Bibliographic references: Lemos 1991 / Archaic Pottery of Chios. The Decorated Styles (p. 130, p. 292, no. 903, pl. 121)
CVA Oxford II / Corpus Vasorum Antiquorum Great Britain 9 Oxford fasicule 2 (p. 81, no. 11, pl. V)
Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (GD.1222) (phase 2)
Jones 1986 / Greek and Cypriot Pottery: a Review of Scientific Studies (p.285, table 3.21, no.2)
Previous owner: Currently owned by: Ashmolean Museum, University of Oxford
